Have only really explored the BC scene as I live here, what are your highlights from the other provinces?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
>>18748507
Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18755289
No seriously avoid that fake yixing stuff its 100% tainted or wont include yixing clay in the first place, ive never seen anyone have an issue with cheap porcelain but get a glazed one if you're in doubt
real yixing clay is really hard so it cannot be made using standard methods like slipcasting or with a jolly-jigger machine so it has to be slab built either by hand or with a half-handmade mold where after using the mold the spout and handle still have to be put on by hand. With the fake stuff they add things to the yixing clay or most likely its just some random clay where they try to make it look more like yixing and to make it usable with cheaper production methods.

>>18756252
>>18756257
google senchado
but basically, just use 2x more leaf per water than you normally would brewing western style. use a small teapot or teacup + strainer
first infusion / steeping around 1 to 1.5 minute, second should be much shorter at like 10-20 seconds, third is 30-45 seconds. use around 70 degrees celsius water for the first two brews, you can use hotter water later if you want to squeeze one or two more cups out of it
I think that's a decent start. of course feel free to adjust it to your liking

No one makes 100ml of tea though, that's not a helpful number. What we're actually dealing with is 6-8 oz (177-236ml) of water, or one mug. If you're using 180ml of water divide that by 60 (ml) for 3 g of tea.
However much water you're using / preferred strength = grams of tea to use

>>18758199
It's alright, depends on how much effort you put in and the post-brew flavoring process. I never experimented with different tea, I've seen some consensus that tea doesn't matter much but I'm sure it affects the flavor to some degree.
My advice, if you're concerned with "is it good" is to pay for some (overpriced, frankly) commercial Kombucha and see if you like it before you launch into actually brewing your own. If you get a plain flavor, you can keep a bit of the liquid and use it to start your culture. The more the better, so maybe pour half the bottle into a small glass and try it and then save the other half to start your first SCOBY (I used significantly less and had acceptable formation but it took way longer than I'd have liked)

>>18754605
>I only eat white chocolate so I'm not worried.
Actually not a bad idea since the bio-accumulation occurs in the cocoa solids not the cocoa butter.

>>18759253
>okay so there's some heavy metals in milk chocolate then. So should we avoid chocolate altogether then?
Leveling with you: Pretty much unless you are an extreme chocoholic in the next few years as manufactures try to reduce their content in the beans.
https://www.npr.org/2022/12/17/1143239430/dark-chocolate-lead-cadmium-consumer-reports
>Johns Hopkins Medicine toxicologist Andrew Stolbach told NPR that maximum allowable dose levels are set to be "very conservative" to account for people with higher risk due to their age and other medical conditions. When the chocolate is consumed in moderate amounts, the lead and cadmium levels are nothing to worry about, he says. "If you make sure that the rest of your diet is good and sufficient in calcium and iron, you protect yourself even more by preventing absorption of some lead and cadmium in your diet."

I've always thought the "Moderation" assurance was conferring false security as if we aren't an over-indulgent nation of consoomers. Asbestos exposure is probably okay too "in moderation". There's no real safe level of heavy metal contamination for humans and the level of danger is dose-dependent. Milk chocolate tends to only have 30-40% Max Cocoa Solids (as they are mostly sugar with a sprinkling of milk solids) so the level of possible heavy metals in them be less than any semi-sweet or dark varieties. Cocoa Powder is 100% solids so prolly shy away from that.

>>18751912
>it doesn't come from the processing the shit comes from the ground
Only the cadmium is soil-originated, the lead is introduced during the post-harvest process (drying and fermenting the beans).
https://www.asyousow.org/blog/2022/8/17/new-report-explains-simple-safe-and-low-cost-solutions-to-reduce-levels-of-lead-and-cadmium-in-chocolate
It's solvable, it just takes time to implement.

posts.sub: Food trend predictions for 2023, and beyond
posts.com:
Happy new year, anons!
What are your food trend predictions for the new year, and the next couple of years?

I'm sure some of you have some knowledge and involvement to say what direction things are probably moving.

I'll post mine in the next post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have 2 major predictions:
1) honey berries/haskap will become a trendy superfood- high in antioxidants, a super hearty plant grows in many climate zones. You will begin to see haskaps used in specialty culinary applications, and then in flavorings like drinks, or smoothies, juices, hot sauces, shit like that. I think they are already growing in popularity in Canada. If you have a chance to have a haskap, or something that uses then as an ingredient, do it! They taste a bit like between a cherry, blueberry, and açai berry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 2023 is the year of rooibos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2) cultured meat
Also known as invitro meat, lab grown meat, and probably some other names. This is meat cells that are grown in a controlled bioreactor lab setting. So, instead of raising a whole cow, they can produce just the meat cells. Back in 2010 a food technologist guest spoke in a college class of mine, and he said we will likely see in vitro meat become common in the next 10 years. The time is due for this technology to become more available. New discoveries have brought this closer to our reality and affordable for the common consumer.

I'm really excited about this, personally. Cruelty free, so vegfags are appeased. It is grown in a controlled environment so less need for animal pharmaceutals, and hormones. Use of far less resources to grow, since you're only growing meat cells, not the entire other bio function of the whole animal. The entière growth environment can be easily kept safer from pathogens and disease. You can customize the taste, amount of fat, and other nutrients. Maybe it could get to the point where people can grow their own.

It likely won't replace your high quality wagyu steak soon, but processed and industrial food applications are plenty- meatballs, McDonald's burgers, chicken nuggies, all are ideal applications for cultured meat.

Pro tip to any anons here wanting to break free from wagie life with as little work as possible.
Scrape up 4700 dollars, not necessary but it makes life easier
Get a CDL-A
Get an Over the Road trucking job and live in your truck for about 5 years. Get your food stuffs from Walmart, you can always get a truck into Walmart. Get a cooker made for truckers. Buy water/drink of choice too
You CAN get internet on the road to shitpost/play vidya. Just spend a lil on a phone plan that gives you a mobile hotspot for a laptop, you're set.
Driving a truck pays fat cash, especially when you don't have to pay rent or a mortgage or send money home to a family. The driving part is best described like this: hours of boredom and seconds of terror. Just drive safe and stay alert and you will be alright.
If you cant get 4700 just find a company that will pay for your CDL training. They will force you to work for them for 6 months in exchange but you will still get paid, just not as much as a good company will. The more experience you get the more pay you can get.
DO. NOT. SIGN. A. LEASE.
Save your Loves/Flying J/Pilot fuel points to get free showers/drinks. Dont go to TA if you can help it.
If you have a gf/wife then dont do this. If you have kids, dont do this. This is for single guys with nothing but free time who want their fat stacks but have no real drive or ambition or talent.
If it works for me, it can work for anyone.
Disclaimer: i am not a boomer who did this 20 years ago. I did it two years ago. Its not paradise by a wide shot. But it is FAR better than ANY faggot retail job I ever had, EVER.

I worked at a Sbarro in a Mall food court for 6 years while getting my 4 yr degree

Free pizza everyday, and better than that we had a barter system with the other places in the food court, so we would trade for anything, bc everyone else wanted pizza

Dated a couple of mall hoes, shout out to the thots at Auntie Anne's

Smoked pot in the walk-in and made mixed drinks all the damn time, especially during the holidays

Got to admit I was real good

Just made my first espresso with my Christmas present to myself, a Wacaco Picopresso and a Kingrinder K4. For a first attempt from someone who doesn't know dick about espresso making, the result was actually quite nice. About as good as the average shot you'd get at a Starbucks; which I know to the aficionado might not be saying much, but for a novice like me, that was kind of the baseline of quality. Now comes the fun part, the next ten shots of espresso where I figure out the right grind setting, the right dosage amount, the right water ratio, the right extraction time, etc.

Incidentally, the K4 on Amazon US is relatively inexpensive. I don't remember if it's a clone of the 1Zpresso JX, JX-Pro, or J-Max, but it's currently sitting at $88 USD, about half the cost of a JX-Pro, and $11 cheaper than the Q2, which is the "entry level" 1Z model. I don't know if it's on sale, or if that's the new price, but it's way cheaper than the various guides and reviews online would suggest.
https://www.amazon.com/KINGrinder-Adjustable-Settings-Aeropress-Consistency/dp/B09WH4B91L

I know it'll sound like shilling, but I
just got a K4 as I mentioned, >>18755344 and immediately loved it. The results I got on the very first "test shot," which I was expecting to throw out so I can fine tune the variables, was so good that I didn't bother making a second one. The recommended setting that Kingrinder gives for espresso is 60 clicks, which was too fine, so I'd recommend doing maybe 58 or 62, whichever direction is coarser. The one gripe I do have with the K4, which isn't a dealbreaker, is that the zero point on the grinder out of the box is bullshit. I've gone though over a dozen different grinders and coffee machines, and dozens of hipster specialty coffees... but always default back to 1kg bags of lavazza from walmart and my krups blade grinder in an aeropress using a scale.

Fuck specialty coffees, fuck expensive grinders, fuck coffee makers and espresso machines. I just want smooth, consistent, and strong coffee with zero acidity or bitterness that I can brew while my frying pan is heating up in the morning. It takes up minimal counter space, just a tiny corner beside my toaster and the only cleanup is dumping grounds and filter directly into the trash and a rinse.

Its just so consistent, so good at being perfectly average: it's the most boringly average cup of coffee I can make in 3 minutes directly in my cup.

>>18758784
> PSD charts for the grinder with various common burr sets involved
I don't think you understand what that would entail. When you see a particle distribution graph, its from a single coffee at a single burr gap at a single roast level at a single rpm at a random humidity, with an unknown alignment. Do you want the same coffee pulled at every single tickmark at every single rpm from 400-700 on every burr that fits on coffees of different roast levels of different origin, density, and processing method?
>anyone have actual PSD charts for some of the so-called "endgame" grinders
If you ask Denis from Kafatek about this he bans you from buying his grinders. Denis started machining his own burrs because of the random changes and inconsistencies from the burrs he was purchasing from ssp and mazzer.
>current setup is allegedly making about 33% fines
We're not doing this again. Buy a df64 and a random set off ssp and fuck off.
>>18758789
Its measuring the radial runout("wobble") of the shaft that rotates the burr. If your rotating burr carrier is wobbling in and out, its going to produce a different distribution than one that's not wobbling. One of the big criticisms of the Weber key is the long shaft thats more prone to wobble than the short one of on the wug. Hard to keep that wobble consistent from grinder to grinder when a random chinese factory is pumping out thousands of units for Breville or Oxo. That wobble is entirely separate from how parallel my burrs are aligned, or how consistent the burrs are to the set the graph you want was made off of. That's the video they sent of my actual unit. Looks to me like 0.012mm of wobble. Its literally 3 engineers in hong kong making the highest quality shit they can. I'm pretty sure kafatek is the same way, <5 guys in seattle cranking out units in small batches. I'd like to get my hands on some of their burrs but you have to have proof of ownership of a grinder to buy them.

>>18759025
I'll just tack these on. You can't taste a graph. It took trying a "high texture" bimodal conical(kinu) next to a "higher clarity" big set of flats(80mm lab sweet) to understand what people actually mean when they say clarity. I've still got nearly all the texture(syrupy, silky, smooth, slick shots), but its like someone cleaned the window I was looking out a bit. There's just way more focus on those blueberry bombs you're obsessed with. When you've got the adjustment to tweak your cup and really start cleaning up/isolating and chasing down that berry bomb note a little bit its amazing what other flavor notes are playing off of it. A shitty but relatable analogy would be how its hard to hear every musician on stage when you're standing right next to the speaker with your ears ringing. I can imagine what I'd "gain" by sacrificing more clarity

The Oxo 8 cup brewer makes 40 ounces of coffee, meaning a cup is 5 oz(150 ml). Similar with the Breville precision brewer, 12 "cups" is 60 oz. The Wilfa Svart Performance, a 4 oz cup. It is not appropriate to punish a child for not wanting to eat a particular food or for not liking a particular sauce. Children's tastes and preferences can change over time, and it is important to respect their individual preferences and allow them to make their own food choices to the extent possible.

Instead of punishing your daughter for not wanting to eat your Quinky Sauce, you could try offering her a variety of different condiments and sauces to choose from, or allow her to customize her own burger with the toppings and condiments that she prefers. You could also try offering a variety of different foods and meals to ensure that there is something that she enjoys eating.

It is also important to remember that children's nutritional needs are different from those of adults, and it is important to offer a balanced and varied diet that meets their specific needs. If you are concerned about your daughter's nutrition, you may want to consider consulting with a healthcare professional or a registered dietitian for advice.

Sorry OP, but maybe Quinky Sauce just ain't where it's had. Instead, you should try the hot-dog chili sauce from Capitol Lunch in New Britain, CT. The location is known to locals as “Crapitol Lunch” and are known to come in and ask for “the shit sauce”. 2 hotdogs and an order of fries is commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You won’t find this on any menu, but if you’re a true local you’ll know. The Famous Sauce is often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by locals and used for dipping. The sauce is also sold for $10 for an 8 ounce container, something many New Britain locals take advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Locals know to order it as a “Big Dump” and the owners aren’t shy about giving a little extra to people who order this way, knowing they’re what’s called a “tool city townie” and thus one of their own.

Get some honey, peanut butter, Nutella, and chocolate chips. Put them in a bowl in roughly equal amounts. Mix them all. Take them out and cut them into small pieces, then roll them into balls. Put the balls on a sheet in a pan and pop them in the fridge for about an hour. You can leave it overnight, which is what I prefer to do. It makes for a fun dessert snack, and it's been a hit at every gathering I've made them for.

Cider is a type of beverage made from the fermented juice of apples. In the United States, cider is often used to refer specifically to a type of sweet, unfiltered apple juice that is made from crushed apples and is often consumed as a non-alcoholic beverage. The term "cider" is also sometimes used to refer to a type of alcoholic beverage made from fermented apple juice, which is similar to but stronger than regular cider. This type of cider is often referred to as "hard cider" to distinguish it from non-alcoholic cider. In other parts of the world, the term "cider" is more commonly used to refer to alcoholic cider, while non-alcoholic apple juice is referred to as simply "apple juice."

(Checked.) That sounds nice. I think it's fair to say that sit-down restaurants and supermarkets are the norm, along with sometimes convenience stores (like at petrol stations). In large urban areas you might (MIGHT) find a Japanese food truck to sushi to-go.


But there is a special category of restaurants worth mentioning: all-you-can-eat Asian buffets. Some are "Chinese", some are "hibachi", they all have a wide selection "American Chinese" sloppa alongside normal American buffet fare... but often also sushi and even sashimi. Of course it's not the same as a proper Japanese restaurant, and the selection is limited. (Lots of California rolls, salmon, tuna, imitation crab. Not so much eel.) But it's usually a little fresher than than supermarket sushi, and you can eat 40 pieces if you're so inclined for like $10-15.

(To be fair, pic related is from an article called "Why You Shouldn't Touch the Sushi at All-You-Can-Eat Buffets", citing concerns about temperature control. But if you visit during peak hours, it's usually not sitting around for very long.)

"Sushi" runs the gamut from bland to spicy as fuck. Just depends on the item being ordered and what the chef shoved in it. The main problem with sushi is you get what you pay for: knock off buffet shit is fucking terrible, middle tier can run the gamut from terrible to great, and high end can be either fantastic or weird. So it is totally possible to have shit experiences with the food, souring newcomers. Conveyor sushi (at least in America) is usually trash tier compared to sit down places. Same with buffet sushi (it is always terrible).

Some stuff is definitely weird and not worth the expense: octopus, squid, the yellow shit I am blanking on the name of right now. However, things like the smoked salmon and bbq eel are delightful and worth their price. There are other fish cuts that taste fantastic, and wagu beef that has been seared is also great (I had it in Australia). I personally love the flavors of certain raw fish over others, but I do get how it isn't for everyone. The rolls are nice too.

But yea, $50 for a meal is fucking expensive as fuck. But high end fish comes with a high end price tag. I've paid $40/lb for King Salmon fresh from the market, so I do get why it comes with a hefty tag at the shop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752376
>anyone who makes sushi knows a safe way to deal with raw fish?

I've been eating raw fish at home for about 4 years now. there are 2 main risks with raw fish:

>parasites
do your research to learn which fish carry the highest risk, but in general, anything that spends time in fresh water can have parasites, while fish that live exclusively in saltwater rarely have parasites. So if you want to eat raw salmon, it's best to freeze it to a temperature and for a time that will kill any parasites. Most places selling "sashimi grade" salmon use that term to indicate it's been frozen properly to eliminate any parasites. Again, do your research here, because freezing to eliminate parasites works the same as pasteurization: you need to hit a target temperature for a set amount of time. Your home freezer may not get cold enough to practically do this.

>salmonella
Salmonella lives in the guts of fish. So when the fish is gutted, if the knife that opens the belly pierces the guts AND pierces the meat, then the meat is contaminated. The only protection you have is to trust your source of fish not to contaminate their product. If you don't trust them, your options are either to cook the fish (this kills the salmonella) or catch your own damn fish and process it yourself. Plenty of reputable places online will ship sashimi-grade, salmonella-free fish to your door. So if you don't trust anyone local, try Fulton, Riviera, or somewhere else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752727
I hate eggplant, but one banchan I love is their take on eggplant. Cooked on high heat it is a little smokey and slightly sweet. The only thing eating Korean food in Korea is better than else ware is local ingredients. For example: The K grandmas go up mountains to pick wild plants that are not in USA. So they have a marinated dish with interesting taste that cant be had stateside. The only one I have not liked is marinated raw crab or anything squid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: https://mykoreankitchen.com/categor<wbr>y/side-dishes-banchan/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752727
Smashed cucumber salad is super simple but always tastes so good

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752727
I like gamjajorim, it's a potato side dish that is sweet and savory.

Chicken-mu is a refreshing alternative to kimchi. It's just picked radish, usually eaten alongside fried chicken hence the name.

Chamchi-jeon is tuna pancakes. Very easy to make, savory too. I like to eat this with a dip made with a ratio of 2 tbsp soy sauce, 2 tsp brown sugar, 2 tsp sesame oil, 2 tsp chili powder, 1 minced garlic, and 1 tbsp hot water.

There's also japchae, and most foreigners typically like it. Not my personal favorite though because it's oily.

>t. Korean

posts.sub: Weird food combos you like but most people haven't tried
posts.com:
For me here are the ones that I tried on another person's suggestion so may be more of a known thing:
>Peanut Butter and Pickle Sandwich
Surprisingly ok. I think I've eaten it 3 times in my life and all three times it was a late night act of desperation that I just so happened to have bread but no normal food toppings. Fortunately peanut butter and pickles tend to last a long time even after opening the jar. The acidity and juicyness of the pickles compliments the peanut butter better than possibly anything else can.

>Meatballs with a sauce primarily made out of grape jelly
Sort of teriyaki beef jerky kind of sweetness flavor. Reminded me of Blues Hog BBQ sauce which has a fuck ton of sugar in it. I wouldn't have it again because I tend to prefer all savory with no sweetness but I can see how a lot of people would like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18753154
Now for the combos that I have personally come up with myself and tried out spontaneously that I turned out to like, so more likely others haven't tried:
>Potato chips and cottage cheese
Use the cottage cheese like a dip that you scoop with the potato chip. It's such a perfect combination that as far as I know am the only person that does this.
To add to this, if you have a particular hot sauce that has great flavor but is hot as fuck to the point where you can't enjoy it, try lacing the cottage cheese up with it first. It will cut the hotness way down and allow you to enjoy the flavor.

>50/50 mayo/sour cream as a dip for fries
If you are someone that eats fries with ranch dressing, try this instead. It has a much fresher taste while satisfying the same kind of craving and gives you the feeling like you just ate a baked potato with sour cream. I have been doing this since I was like 8 years old, no idea where I got the idea but my parents say it was all me, no one else in my family does it and they remember when I first concocted the mixture. I know the Dutch eat fries with straight up mayo but this mix is superior IMO.

>Mac and cheese made with (a lot) of vinegar
I originally started putting a bit of vinegar in my mac noodles to keep them from sticking together too much after boiling. One day I accidentally put way more than normal in, and it turned out to be really fucking good in the way that salt/vinegar chips are good. I'm sure this one won't be for everybody but if you are a vinegar fiend like myself you will like this shit. I like to use apple cider vinegar.

I would really like to hear about other stuff like this if anyone has any.

>>18751311
Pizza is a highly subjective food, and different people have different tastes and preferences. Some people may prefer the thin, crisp crust and simple toppings of New York-style pizza, while others may prefer the thicker, softer crust and more complex toppings of Detroit-style pizza. There is no one "best" style of pizza - it's all a matter of personal taste. That being said, it's perfectly okay to have your own opinions and preferences when it comes to food. If you think Detroit-style pizza is the best, then that's your opinion and it's perfectly valid.

>>18754238
It's true that different regions of the world have their own unique styles of pizza, and many people may not have had the opportunity to try all of them. Pizza is a global food, and there are many different variations to be found around the world, each with its own unique characteristics and flavors. The Okanagan region of British Columbia is known for its fresh, locally sourced ingredients, and it's possible that wood-fired pizza made with these ingredients could be delicious. It's always interesting to try new foods and discover new flavors and culinary traditions from different parts of the world.

>>18746943
County of origin, type of sugar cane byproduct used (cane juice, sugar, molasses, other), still used (pot, column, both) and aging are the most important factors. Good luck finding most of that out with your average rum. Agricole is a legal term and usually means cane juice and a vegetal and herbal flavor. Age means little because it's so hot in the tropics and some of the barrel houses are at high altitude.

Try to find a local cutlery shop that offers free sharpening. Well worth it if you don't want to bother getting your own whetstones and learning to sharpen yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
what's your budget and aesthetic sense or knife handling preference and where are you located my friend
if you want something that works very well without costing much, just get a victorinox
if like japanese knives, look up independent japanese knife shops in your country, there is a huge range of price points available. you probably want a 210 or 240mm gyuto or kiritsuke, but if you like japanese cooking a smaller santoku or bunka is great
wusthof is dependable for german style and k sabatier is a good french option. i personally like japanese and french style knives but only own japanese ones
make sure you have access to a good sharpening service or just buy whetstone or two in appropriate grits for the kind of steel you have. 800 is good for softer western style knives, a 1000 and maybe an additional one anywhere from 3-6000 is good for japanese ones. lower grits are great for fixing up any fucked up old knives

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18756412
For whisky I generally find that the ABV going up brings out more of the flavours, especially flavours which tend to linger at the back. Glenfiddich for me has always been more fruity with hardly any peat and not that much oak. And while I do still appreciate the Glenfiddich 18 40% as it’s really a decent bottle it’s also kinda annoying that I often feel that the flavours could be exposed a little more, because there’s really a lot going on. I agree with you though that one sign of a good liquor is having a silly high ABV while not actually tasting any of the alcohol, which Glenfiddich knows how to master. So it’s somewhat aggravating that they’re purposefully nerfing themselves. I don’t think anyone really knows why but the rumour is that they just want to get more bottles out. Glenfiddich has also been doing this thing where they’ll do restricted releases of higher ABV bottles like the one I just acquired (it’s pretty much limited to duty free merchants at airports and only in select countries). And from what I heard the original 18 43% can still be acquired but only at their distillery. It’s bloody annoying because they know their shit. The 15 VAT 03 50.2% I got was only about 80US$ and alcohol taxes in my country are stupid high. So they also know how to release a fucking stupid good product at a very decent price. Yeah. Go figure. I both love and hate Glenfiddich, but at least I managed to get one bottle of the VAT 03 and I’ll enjoy every last drop of it.

Some, like myself, don't want to buy into the frantic madness most seem to be willing to throw themselves into just to forget, or at least distract themselves for a night, of the implications of $6/dozen eggs, $20 fast food "meals" and the rapid whipsawing of social narrative we've been rollercoastering on.

It's one thing to SAY you're going to be better in the upcoming year... ...very much another to DO it.

>>18756914
>>18756863
>Flippy food
>Rice - Everything. Is Eaten. With Rice. *everything*
>Vinegar. Vinegar is used IN EVERYTHING. Vinegar, Garlic, and Black Peppercorn are the holy trinity (soy sauce, fish sauce, bayleaf honorable mention)
>Bagnet - boiled then dried then crispy fried pork belly seasoned with garlic, black peppercorns, bay leaves, and salt. It is eaten with rice.
>Silog - portmanteau of sinangag (fried rice) and itlog (fried egg). Literally what it says on the tin. Usually served at breakfast. Often paired with another meat or sauce that gets added to the name, like a short order call out. Ex. Tapsilog (most common), which is tapa (dried or cured beef, pork, mutton, venison or horse meat), sinagag, and Itlog. There are specialty breakfast places that'll serve just variations of this called Tapsi. If they try to serve you plain boiled rice or plain rice with garlic flakes over it (sinaing) then they are JEWS trying to rip you off, Sinangag specifically refers to rice fried with garlic
>Lumpia - yes the same papery crepe springroll that's on your chinese takeout menu. This is part of the problem of flip dishes, Phillipines have been migrated, invaded, and or colonized by literally everyone. Lumpia came to Phillipines from southern chinese immigrants in 900-1500 ad
>Adobo - meat and vegetables simmered & browned in a flavorful sauce. Phillipine adobo sprang up independent of Spanish Adobo and uses different ingredients - specifically Vinegar (especially important), Bayleaf, Black Peppercorn, and Soy Sauce. Adobo in Phillipines also tends to refer to the cooking process, rather than a specific dish - so you can have anything adobo'd, as long as that would taste good cooked in vinegar and served with garlic fried rice
>Daing - Fish (usually milk fish) dried, maybe salted, then marinated in garlick vinegar and fried.

the pattern is vinegar and garlic. It's probably native if it has that instead of tomato or pepper

I have leftover taco meat, so I threw together some tacos. Pic related.

The taco meat I made with instructions from Ethan Chlebowski's meal prep video. It's actually very well made, and has totally changed how I view meal prep. It's basically braised beef finished off in an adobo chili sauce. It's delicious, and since I only made enough for a few meals, I can switch to a different beef dish instantly without worrying about waste.

Then I added in some Cotija Mexican cheese, curtosey from the Mexican grocery store on the other side of town. I finished it off with lettuce, onions, tomatoes, and avocado, and some left over Chipotle chips + their hot salsa, and some nacho cheese dip. Overall, a pretty depressing meal for myself on New Years, but it's not the most depressing thing I've eating on New Years, trust me on that.

>>18757324
Milanesa is a dish popular in Argentina, Uruguay, South of Brazil that's made by breading a meat (or chicken) cutlet in flour, egg and breadcrumbs and then deep frying it.

It's similar to the German schnitzel, if you know what that is.

Typically is served with mashed potatoes or french fries.

The Milanesa Napolitana is a regular milanesa that gets ham, cheese and oregano (sometimes tomato sauce) and baked, similar to chicken parm if you're American.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18752041
We are both Mexican living in Mexico eating mexican food.

I am from Sinaloa and she is from Guadalajara, so we are mixing some recipes.

Here is something that she discovered. There is a place in Culiacan named Palomar de los pobres. Just some grilled meat, nothing special, but the beans they serve are pretty good.
It has been a mystery trying to find the trick to make those. However, the first time she tried, she told me that they used “manteca de puerco”, pork lard. When we got back to Guadalajara, she made beans with pork lard and had the same fucking flavour.

Not the best pic but this is what I found.

It is funny because all the people from Culiacan tried to replicate those beans but my wife told me that it is a Guadalajara style.

>Why were they blowing silica dust into your home
They were attempting to tuck point the masonry on the two flat I rented a floor in. Everything from federal OSHA regulations to local building codes requires them to have vacuums hooked up to their grinders and saws to collect dust, and forbid using brooms to collect dust. Instead to save a couple grand on labor costs, because it is a hassle to have a shop vac on scaffolding, they used leaf blowers to distribute the dust across the general area so they could claim it was always that dusty. All of our property wound up contaminated, I had a blood nose for two+ months, my wife was on an inhaler for 6 months.

Abandonment in our state allows a landlord to dispose of all property within an apartment.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18759082
It's much older than that. Lemon pigs are mentioned in books dating back to the 17th century. There is evidence of porcine citrus effigies in cave settlements on the island of Sumatra.
President Rutherford B. Hayes was once gifted a lemon pig, which is still preserved in a museum 130 years later. For those of you who throw your pig after a week, let this bring you shame.
King Charlemagne gifted a similar such pig to the Duke of Jersey in a bid to end the fourth crusade.

posts.com:
Air fryers can be a convenient and energy-efficient way to cook food, and they can be especially useful for people who are cooking for themselves. However, it is important to note that an air fryer is not a magic solution to healthy eating and weight loss. The healthiness of your meals will depend on the types of food you choose to cook and how you prepare them.

That being said, air fryers can be a useful tool for achieving your fitness goals. Because they use hot air instead of oil to cook food, they can help reduce the amount of fat and calories in your meals. This can be especially beneficial if you are trying to reduce your intake of unhealthy fats.

It's difficult to say what the "best" food pairing is, as it really depends on personal preference. However, some other classic food pairings that may be considered by some to be just as good as pizza and beer include:

Burgers and fries with a cold glass of milk
Grilled cheese sandwich with tomato soup
Spaghetti and meatballs with a glass of red wine
Sushi and sake
BBQ ribs and a cold craft beer
Lobster and butter with a bottle of white wine
Tacos and margaritas
Steak and potatoes with a Cabernet Sauvignon
Fried chicken and coleslaw with a sweet tea
Bangers and mash with a pint of ale
Again, these are just a few examples, and there are countless other great food and drink pairings to enjoy.

O-ok bro, so you don't actually have any advice or tips? Thanks for replying I guess, i'm also lonely if you want to keep chatting (not insulting you)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18758720
1. The rice better be short grain rice, or you are fucked.
2. They add stuff to the rice to make it sticky, usually some mixture involving rice wine and other stuff. Look it up.
3. Sushi rolling mat - add cling film to wrap it
4. Nori sheet goes down first, cut to size
5. Rice - paddle it onto the nori
6. Spread the rice into a thin layer over nori
7. In a line, add your fillings (away from edges)
8. Add sauces, don't use soy, that won't work. Use jap mayo base and add stuff to it. Or use a thick teriyaki.
9. Roll, move the mat out of the way, then finish the roll, tuck and squeeze.
10. Cover roll in cling film, then wet sharp knife and cut into pieces through the film

Soy goes in the dipping dish. Do no use in replacement for a sauce.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> is there such a thing as too much fruit in your diet
Yes

Fruits tend to contain a lot of fructose is turned into glucose and fat in the liver. When the liver does this process, the fat accumulates around the liver, and that "visceral fat" around and in your organs is correlated with poor health. The big name for it getting really bad is "fatty liver disease" which is often associated with alcohol, but fructose causes it for the same reason alcohol does.

Fruit has benefits though. Citrus, especially lemon, increases absorption of minerals that are connected to oxalate, and it also increases the excretion of oxalate, which reduces the risk of kidney stones. This makes it good to add lemon juice to a salad with things like spinach, because spinach is high in minerals and oxalate, but the oxalate just takes all of the minerals from you.
There's also the antioxidant effects from grapes' resveratrol and pomegranates' anthocyanin.
Fruits have a lot of prebiotic and probiotic fiber, which is important for your gut health, but many of these fibers can be gotten from vegetables too.
Plus if you want something sweet, it's better to eat fruit than to eat a candy bar.

posts.com:
I think reverse sear is good.

Lately I've been using the following method:
Sear both sides, very hot pan.
Let rest for a few mins while pan cools down
Cook the rest of the steak on a much lower temperature until desired doneness. Makes it impossible to fuck up, you can measure it with a thermometer, but even if you don't you can feel it without worrying about overcooking your steak by leaving it on for 10 seconds too long. And you don't have to worry about burning the butter/garlic or whatever you're basting with. Also surprisingly the lower temperature still helps improve the crust on the outside of the steak.

>>18757100
-white distilled vinegar
-sugar
-salt
-caraway
-bayleaf
-small amount of garlic slices
-some mustard seeds.

I cool the brine/marinade completely before adding it to the onions; since the liquid is cold, wait at least couple of days before consuming, otherwise the onions will be bitter.

No frills. Just classic made the right way.

posts.sub: Do you have a go-to quick dipping sauce recipe?
posts.com:
I like alot of complex dips, love making my jalapeno ranches from scratch, peanut sauce, various shit.

BUT my go-to for everyday quick dipping is usually as follows

-3 parts Sour Cream
-1 part ranch
-pepper
-Buffalo sauce (BWW's and Franks red buffalo mixed together)
-Sriracha

Quickly stir those together and you've got something quick and easy and delicious

Anybody got a quick dipping recipe?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: nothing fancy, just honey, mustard, and mayo

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I sauté a a teaspoon of minced garlic in a tablespoon of olive oil Once it's lightly browned I add crushed red pepper and let it crisp for 45 seconds or so. Then I add 2 teaspoons if paprika and take it off the heat.
Mix the above with mayo, sour cream, lemon juice, and black pepper. I've tried dozens of different dipping sauces and this is where my journey has brought me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

Nicaraguan cigars are as good or better than Cuban cigars and have been for a while.
When Castro took over, some tobacco growers took their best seeds and traveled around Latin America looking for the ideal location to replant: Nicaragua. Nicaraguan cigars aren’t as prestigious as Cubans, but they’re as good or better for a fraction of the cost, not to mention that it’s very hard to get Cubans in some countries.
Fun fact: A few years ago, Cuban tobacco was devastated by a hurricane, so the producers went abroad in search of the best seed: Nicaragua. So, the Cubans you’re smoking today were likely grown from Nicaraguan seed.

Bullshit. A Swiss pharmacist called Neuhaus moved to Brussels and coated his pills in chocolate because they weren't selling. His Belgian son started coating fruits, nuts and syrups and called them pralines after duke Choiseul du Plessis-Praslin, a French duke of the 1600's who liked to coat nuts with cacao (actual chocolate was invented by the Dutch Conrad Van Houten, in 1828).

It became a hit on the world exhibition in Ghent, Belgium in 1913, and has been a worldwide hit ever since. The quality and know how are still very Belgian, the Swiss protestants have more marketing and money, that's all there is to it.

hello fellow jack/ck/offs.
i inquired about the cooking temp and time of a chicken ballotine 2 days ago. today i cooked one(180c for 2 hours).
deboning process is straight forward and like i said the last time i used the jacques pepin method. i did it in 15 minutes, its not that time consuming so im planning on doing this on the regular.
the stuffing was chicken liver farce. recipe is as follows;
render and brown 150 grams of cured pork belly(non smoked), add 75 grams of mushrooms and 50 grams of shallots(i used white onion because idgaf), add 300 grams of livers, brown ahrd and season with the usual suspects and allspice.Remove the contents and deglaze the pan with white wine(i used red wine because who the fuck cares), reduce to syrup and add. process everything and add 2 eggs when its cooled enough.
once cool you stuff the bird and truss it, you can sew the back skin if you are a fancy nigger.

it was rich as fuck. i served it with dauphinoise potatoes and homemade cherry wineand i nearly died because i ate two servings.also whilst making the wine i cracked several cherry pits so i was afraid of the cynanide. i drank 3 glasses and im fine so its okay.
in refards to the wine i didnt use any pectinase, i fucking lost 60% to rackings to clarify it. will definetly use pectinase next time.

happy new years. also post stuff you cooked for today that was a challenge and an experiment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ez ass meal for two with leftover pasta cooking for more? buy more sausage

1 28oz can of whole tomatoes (san marzano style preferred) -1.19
1 lb of linguine -89 cents
5 tablespoons of butter - 20 cents worth?
1 yellow onion -79 cents
2 one dollar hot Italian sausages from the deli

should be close to 5 dollars

Combine the tomatoes, butter and onion(only cut in half) in a pan and cook for 45 mins breaking the tomatoes down with a spatula. No less no more time. Salt and pepper to taste. Start boiling pasta water 5 mins before your 45 min timer is up.
Once done remove the sauce and remove the onion from the sauce. Wipe out the pan add in the sausage and brown them up cook for 12-14 mins or so. While they are cooking cook your pasta for 10 mins or until al dente.

Serve the sauce over the pasta and slice up the sausage and place it on the side of the pasta. Place 2-3 of the onion pieces on the side of the pasta as well they should be well cooked and translucent. Grate some parmesan over the pasta if you have some. Can serve with a buttered french bread chunk as well.

Pic related and trust me its one of the best sauces you can make. Look up Marcella Hazan tomato sauce.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

>>18746663
Yes they are. Storing glucose as glycogen requires energy. While yes, the body is perfectly capable of producing glucose from sources that are not carbs it does not store that glucose as glycogen for future use. That glucose goes straight to use as the body requires glucose to operate. It makes no sense for our bodies to spend extra energy to produce excess glugoce that is then stored when you are already missing glucose and have to first inefficiently create glucose from other sources. And when we're talking glycogen stores it's obvious that I'm talking about the large scale stores. Sure small amounts might be stored as a buffer but adults have multiple kg of glycogen when their glycogen stores are full. It's also why everyone loses weight at first on keto even if they eat the same caloric intake. They expens their glycogen stores but can't replenish them. It's also why people gain weight when they stop keto while keeping the same caloric intake. Those same glycogen stores get filled as they eat carbs.

tipping is absolute retardation and a scam
basically a hidden tax that isn't shown on the menu, a win-win scam for the owner: he make the client pay for the waiter wage and he put a lower price on the menu incentivizing people to buy more

The only counter-argument that could make sense is that "the waiter will work harder and offer a better service", but this fall flat on many angles: a shitty family restaurant doesn't fucking do half the thing a proper server from a proper high class restaurant does nor does he need actual training, tipping culture basically make tipping mandatory which remove the actual incentive as people are tipping out of cultural obligation and not due to the actual good service that made them go "woah this nigga did good, il give him some money" and finally making sure the waiter does his job properly is the manager's job not the client's. I have never had an actual good service at a family/lower-class restaurant that deserved the tip that inflate the price by 10 to 20%. With the current tech, you could have an app or an interface that allow you to place order and tell you when they are ready so you can go get them yourself, who know when you will be able to do the last part with robots; who would pay a 20% tax when the job being done can be replaced by a fucking app.
This shit make me mad, especially considering actual waiter at high class place have to know how to serve the food, how to tell clueless clients how to best appreciate the food, how to cut the food when it's too big ie a whole roast, etc.
